17#include <config.h>
18
19#include <stdbool.h>
20#include <stddef.h>
21#include <inttypes.h>
22
23#if defined(sun) && (defined(__sparc) || defined(__sparc__))
24#include <synch.h> /* for smt_pause(3c) */
25#endif
26
27#include <isc/atomic.h>
28#include <isc/magic.h>
29#include <isc/platform.h>
30#include <isc/print.h>
31#include <isc/rwlock.h>
32#include <isc/util.h>
33
34#define RWLOCK_MAGIC ISC_MAGIC('R', 'W', 'L', 'k')
35#define VALID_RWLOCK(rwl) ISC_MAGIC_VALID(rwl, RWLOCK_MAGIC)
36
37#ifndef RWLOCK_DEFAULT_READ_QUOTA
38#define RWLOCK_DEFAULT_READ_QUOTA 4
39#endif
40
41#ifndef RWLOCK_DEFAULT_WRITE_QUOTA
42#define RWLOCK_DEFAULT_WRITE_QUOTA 4
43#endif
44
45#ifndef RWLOCK_MAX_ADAPTIVE_COUNT
46#define RWLOCK_MAX_ADAPTIVE_COUNT 100
47#endif
48
49#ifdef __lint__
50# define isc_rwlock_pause()
51#else
52#if defined(_MSC_VER)
53# include <intrin.h>
54# define isc_rwlock_pause() YieldProcessor()
55#elif defined(__x86_64__)
56# include <immintrin.h>
57# define isc_rwlock_pause() _mm_pause()
58#elif defined(__i386__)
59# define isc_rwlock_pause() __asm__ __volatile__ ("rep; nop")
60#elif defined(__ia64__)
61# define isc_rwlock_pause() __asm__ __volatile__ ("hint @pause")
62#elif defined(__arm__) && defined(_ARM_ARCH_6)
63# define isc_rwlock_pause() __asm__ __volatile__ ("yield")
64#elif defined(sun) && (defined(__sparc) || defined(__sparc__))
65# define isc_rwlock_pause() smt_pause()
66// Disable pause, only works on v9
67#elif (defined(__sparc) || defined(__sparc__)) && defined(notdef)
68# define isc_rwlock_pause() __asm__ __volatile__ ("pause")
69#elif defined(__ppc__) || defined(_ARCH_PPC) || \
70 defined(_ARCH_PWR) || defined(_ARCH_PWR2) || defined(_POWER)
71# define isc_rwlock_pause() __asm__ volatile ("or 27,27,27")
72#else
73# define isc_rwlock_pause()
74#endif
75#endif
76
77static isc_result_t
78isc__rwlock_lock(isc_rwlock_t *rwl, isc_rwlocktype_t type);
79
80#ifdef ISC_RWLOCK_TRACE
81#include <stdio.h> /* Required for fprintf/stderr. */
82#include <isc/thread.h> /* Required for isc_thread_self(). */
83
84static void
85print_lock(const char *operation, isc_rwlock_t *rwl, isc_rwlocktype_t type) {
86 fprintf(stderr,
87 "rwlock %p thread %lu %s(%s): "
88 "write_requests=%u, write_completions=%u, "
89 "cnt_and_flag=0x%x, readers_waiting=%u, "
90 "write_granted=%u, write_quota=%u\n",
91 rwl, isc_thread_self(), operation,
92 (type == isc_rwlocktype_read ? "read" : "write"),
93 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, memory_order_relaxed),
94 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed),
95 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, memory_order_relaxed),
96 rwl->readers_waiting,
97 rwl->write_granted, rwl->write_quota);
98}
99#endif /* ISC_RWLOCK_TRACE */
100
101isc_result_t
102isc_rwlock_init(isc_rwlock_t *rwl, unsigned int read_quota,
103 unsigned int write_quota)
104{
105 REQUIRE(rwl != NULL);
106
107 /*
108 * In case there's trouble initializing, we zero magic now. If all
109 * goes well, we'll set it to RWLOCK_MAGIC.
110 */
111 rwl->magic = 0;
112
113 rwl->spins = 0;
114 atomic_init(&rwl->write_requests, 0);
115 atomic_init(&rwl->write_completions, 0);
116 atomic_init(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, 0);
117 rwl->readers_waiting = 0;
118 rwl->write_granted = 0;
119 if (read_quota != 0) {
120 UNEXPECTED_ERROR(__FILE__, __LINE__,
121 "read quota is not supported");
122 }
123 if (write_quota == 0)
124 write_quota = RWLOCK_DEFAULT_WRITE_QUOTA;
125 rwl->write_quota = write_quota;
126
127 isc_mutex_init(&rwl->lock);
128
129 isc_condition_init(&rwl->readable);
130 isc_condition_init(&rwl->writeable);
131
132 rwl->magic = RWLOCK_MAGIC;
133
134 return (ISC_R_SUCCESS);
135}
136
137void
138isc_rwlock_destroy(isc_rwlock_t *rwl) {
139 REQUIRE(VALID_RWLOCK(rwl));
140
141 REQUIRE(atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, memory_order_relaxed) ==
142 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed) &&
143 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, memory_order_relaxed) == 0 && rwl->readers_waiting == 0);
144
145 rwl->magic = 0;
146 (void)isc_condition_destroy(&rwl->readable);
147 (void)isc_condition_destroy(&rwl->writeable);
148 isc_mutex_destroy(&rwl->lock);
149}
150
151/*
152 * When some architecture-dependent atomic operations are available,
153 * rwlock can be more efficient than the generic algorithm defined below.
154 * The basic algorithm is described in the following URL:
155 * http://www.cs.rochester.edu/u/scott/synchronization/pseudocode/rw.html
156 *
157 * The key is to use the following integer variables modified atomically:
158 * write_requests, write_completions, and cnt_and_flag.
159 *
160 * write_requests and write_completions act as a waiting queue for writers
161 * in order to ensure the FIFO order. Both variables begin with the initial
162 * value of 0. When a new writer tries to get a write lock, it increments
163 * write_requests and gets the previous value of the variable as a "ticket".
164 * When write_completions reaches the ticket number, the new writer can start
165 * writing. When the writer completes its work, it increments
166 * write_completions so that another new writer can start working. If the
167 * write_requests is not equal to write_completions, it means a writer is now
168 * working or waiting. In this case, a new readers cannot start reading, or
169 * in other words, this algorithm basically prefers writers.
170 *
171 * cnt_and_flag is a "lock" shared by all readers and writers. This integer
172 * variable is a kind of structure with two members: writer_flag (1 bit) and
173 * reader_count (31 bits). The writer_flag shows whether a writer is working,
174 * and the reader_count shows the number of readers currently working or almost
175 * ready for working. A writer who has the current "ticket" tries to get the
176 * lock by exclusively setting the writer_flag to 1, provided that the whole
177 * 32-bit is 0 (meaning no readers or writers working). On the other hand,
178 * a new reader tries to increment the "reader_count" field provided that
179 * the writer_flag is 0 (meaning there is no writer working).
180 *
181 * If some of the above operations fail, the reader or the writer sleeps
182 * until the related condition changes. When a working reader or writer
183 * completes its work, some readers or writers are sleeping, and the condition
184 * that suspended the reader or writer has changed, it wakes up the sleeping
185 * readers or writers.
186 *
187 * As already noted, this algorithm basically prefers writers. In order to
188 * prevent readers from starving, however, the algorithm also introduces the
189 * "writer quota" (Q). When Q consecutive writers have completed their work,
190 * suspending readers, the last writer will wake up the readers, even if a new
191 * writer is waiting.
192 *
193 * Implementation specific note: due to the combination of atomic operations
194 * and a mutex lock, ordering between the atomic operation and locks can be
195 * very sensitive in some cases. In particular, it is generally very important
196 * to check the atomic variable that requires a reader or writer to sleep after
197 * locking the mutex and before actually sleeping; otherwise, it could be very
198 * likely to cause a deadlock. For example, assume "var" is a variable
199 * atomically modified, then the corresponding code would be:
200 * if (var == need_sleep) {
201 * LOCK(lock);
202 * if (var == need_sleep)
203 * WAIT(cond, lock);
204 * UNLOCK(lock);
205 * }
206 * The second check is important, since "var" is protected by the atomic
207 * operation, not by the mutex, and can be changed just before sleeping.
208 * (The first "if" could be omitted, but this is also important in order to
209 * make the code efficient by avoiding the use of the mutex unless it is
210 * really necessary.)
211 */
212
213#define WRITER_ACTIVE 0x1
214#define READER_INCR 0x2
215
216static isc_result_t
217isc__rwlock_lock(isc_rwlock_t *rwl, isc_rwlocktype_t type) {
218 int32_t cntflag;
219
220 REQUIRE(VALID_RWLOCK(rwl));
221
222#ifdef ISC_RWLOCK_TRACE
223 print_lock("prelock", rwl, type);
224#endif
225
226 if (type == isc_rwlocktype_read) {
227 if (atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, memory_order_relaxed) !=
228 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed))
229 {
230 /* there is a waiting or active writer */
231 LOCK(&rwl->lock);
232 if (atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, memory_order_relaxed) !=
233 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed)) {
234 rwl->readers_waiting++;
235 WAIT(&rwl->readable, &rwl->lock);
236 rwl->readers_waiting--;
237 }
238 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
239 }
240
241 cntflag = atomic_fetch_add_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag,
242 READER_INCR,
243 memory_order_relaxed);
244 POST(cntflag);
245 while (1) {
246 if ((atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, memory_order_relaxed) & WRITER_ACTIVE) == 0)
247 break;
248
249 /* A writer is still working */
250 LOCK(&rwl->lock);
251 rwl->readers_waiting++;
252 if ((atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, memory_order_relaxed) & WRITER_ACTIVE) != 0) {
253 WAIT(&rwl->readable, &rwl->lock);
254 }
255 rwl->readers_waiting--;
256 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
257
258 /*
259 * Typically, the reader should be able to get a lock
260 * at this stage:
261 * (1) there should have been no pending writer when
262 * the reader was trying to increment the
263 * counter; otherwise, the writer should be in
264 * the waiting queue, preventing the reader from
265 * proceeding to this point.
266 * (2) once the reader increments the counter, no
267 * more writer can get a lock.
268 * Still, it is possible another writer can work at
269 * this point, e.g. in the following scenario:
270 * A previous writer unlocks the writer lock.
271 * This reader proceeds to point (1).
272 * A new writer appears, and gets a new lock before
273 * the reader increments the counter.
274 * The reader then increments the counter.
275 * The previous writer notices there is a waiting
276 * reader who is almost ready, and wakes it up.
277 * So, the reader needs to confirm whether it can now
278 * read explicitly (thus we loop). Note that this is
279 * not an infinite process, since the reader has
280 * incremented the counter at this point.
281 */
282 }
283
284 /*
285 * If we are temporarily preferred to writers due to the writer
286 * quota, reset the condition (race among readers doesn't
287 * matter).
288 */
289 rwl->write_granted = 0;
290 } else {
291 int32_t prev_writer;
292
293 /* enter the waiting queue, and wait for our turn */
294 prev_writer = atomic_fetch_add_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, 1,
295 memory_order_relaxed);
296 while (atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed) != prev_writer) {
297 LOCK(&rwl->lock);
298 if (atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed) != prev_writer) {
299 WAIT(&rwl->writeable, &rwl->lock);
300 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
301 continue;
302 }
303 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
304 break;
305 }
306
307 while (1) {
308 int_fast32_t zero = 0;
309 if (atomic_compare_exchange_strong_explicit
310 (&rwl->cnt_and_flag, &zero, WRITER_ACTIVE,
311 memory_order_relaxed, memory_order_relaxed))
312 {
313 break;
314 }
315
316 /* Another active reader or writer is working. */
317 LOCK(&rwl->lock);
318 if (atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, memory_order_relaxed) != 0) {
319 WAIT(&rwl->writeable, &rwl->lock);
320 }
321 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
322 }
323
324 INSIST((atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, memory_order_relaxed) & WRITER_ACTIVE));
325 rwl->write_granted++;
326 }
327
328#ifdef ISC_RWLOCK_TRACE
329 print_lock("postlock", rwl, type);
330#endif
331
332 return (ISC_R_SUCCESS);
333}
334
335isc_result_t
336isc_rwlock_lock(isc_rwlock_t *rwl, isc_rwlocktype_t type) {
337 int32_t cnt = 0;
338 int32_t max_cnt = rwl->spins * 2 + 10;
339 isc_result_t result = ISC_R_SUCCESS;
340
341 if (max_cnt > RWLOCK_MAX_ADAPTIVE_COUNT)
342 max_cnt = RWLOCK_MAX_ADAPTIVE_COUNT;
343
344 do {
345 if (cnt++ >= max_cnt) {
346 result = isc__rwlock_lock(rwl, type);
347 break;
348 }
349 isc_rwlock_pause();
350 } while (isc_rwlock_trylock(rwl, type) != ISC_R_SUCCESS);
351
352 rwl->spins += (cnt - rwl->spins) / 8;
353
354 return (result);
355}
356
357isc_result_t
358isc_rwlock_trylock(isc_rwlock_t *rwl, isc_rwlocktype_t type) {
359 int32_t cntflag;
360
361 REQUIRE(VALID_RWLOCK(rwl));
362
363#ifdef ISC_RWLOCK_TRACE
364 print_lock("prelock", rwl, type);
365#endif
366
367 if (type == isc_rwlocktype_read) {
368 /* If a writer is waiting or working, we fail. */
369 if (atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, memory_order_relaxed) !=
370 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed))
371 return (ISC_R_LOCKBUSY);
372
373 /* Otherwise, be ready for reading. */
374 cntflag = atomic_fetch_add_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag,
375 READER_INCR,
376 memory_order_relaxed);
377 if ((cntflag & WRITER_ACTIVE) != 0) {
378 /*
379 * A writer is working. We lose, and cancel the read
380 * request.
381 */
382 cntflag = atomic_fetch_sub_explicit
383 (&rwl->cnt_and_flag, READER_INCR,
384 memory_order_relaxed);
385 /*
386 * If no other readers are waiting and we've suspended
387 * new writers in this short period, wake them up.
388 */
389 if (cntflag == READER_INCR &&
390 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed) !=
391 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, memory_order_relaxed)) {
392 LOCK(&rwl->lock);
393 BROADCAST(&rwl->writeable);
394 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
395 }
396
397 return (ISC_R_LOCKBUSY);
398 }
399 } else {
400 /* Try locking without entering the waiting queue. */
401 int_fast32_t zero = 0;
402 if (!atomic_compare_exchange_strong_explicit
403 (&rwl->cnt_and_flag, &zero, WRITER_ACTIVE,
404 memory_order_relaxed, memory_order_relaxed))
405 {
406 return (ISC_R_LOCKBUSY);
407 }
408
409 /*
410 * XXXJT: jump into the queue, possibly breaking the writer
411 * order.
412 */
413 atomic_fetch_sub_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, 1,
414 memory_order_relaxed);
415
416 rwl->write_granted++;
417 }
418
419#ifdef ISC_RWLOCK_TRACE
420 print_lock("postlock", rwl, type);
421#endif
422
423 return (ISC_R_SUCCESS);
424}
425
426isc_result_t
427isc_rwlock_tryupgrade(isc_rwlock_t *rwl) {
428 REQUIRE(VALID_RWLOCK(rwl));
429
430 {
431 int_fast32_t reader_incr = READER_INCR;
432
433 /* Try to acquire write access. */
434 atomic_compare_exchange_strong_explicit
435 (&rwl->cnt_and_flag, &reader_incr, WRITER_ACTIVE,
436 memory_order_relaxed, memory_order_relaxed);
437 /*
438 * There must have been no writer, and there must have
439 * been at least one reader.
440 */
441 INSIST((reader_incr & WRITER_ACTIVE) == 0 &&
442 (reader_incr & ~WRITER_ACTIVE) != 0);
443
444 if (reader_incr == READER_INCR) {
445 /*
446 * We are the only reader and have been upgraded.
447 * Now jump into the head of the writer waiting queue.
448 */
449 atomic_fetch_sub_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, 1,
450 memory_order_relaxed);
451 } else
452 return (ISC_R_LOCKBUSY);
453
454 }
455
456 return (ISC_R_SUCCESS);
457}
458
459void
460isc_rwlock_downgrade(isc_rwlock_t *rwl) {
461 int32_t prev_readers;
462
463 REQUIRE(VALID_RWLOCK(rwl));
464
465 {
466 /* Become an active reader. */
467 prev_readers = atomic_fetch_add_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag,
468 READER_INCR,
469 memory_order_relaxed);
470 /* We must have been a writer. */
471 INSIST((prev_readers & WRITER_ACTIVE) != 0);
472
473 /* Complete write */
474 atomic_fetch_sub_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, WRITER_ACTIVE,
475 memory_order_relaxed);
476 atomic_fetch_add_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, 1,
477 memory_order_relaxed);
478 }
479
480 /* Resume other readers */
481 LOCK(&rwl->lock);
482 if (rwl->readers_waiting > 0)
483 BROADCAST(&rwl->readable);
484 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
485}
486
487isc_result_t
488isc_rwlock_unlock(isc_rwlock_t *rwl, isc_rwlocktype_t type) {
489 int32_t prev_cnt;
490
491 REQUIRE(VALID_RWLOCK(rwl));
492
493#ifdef ISC_RWLOCK_TRACE
494 print_lock("preunlock", rwl, type);
495#endif
496
497 if (type == isc_rwlocktype_read) {
498 prev_cnt = atomic_fetch_sub_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag,
499 READER_INCR,
500 memory_order_relaxed);
501 /*
502 * If we're the last reader and any writers are waiting, wake
503 * them up. We need to wake up all of them to ensure the
504 * FIFO order.
505 */
506 if (prev_cnt == READER_INCR &&
507 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed) !=
508 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, memory_order_relaxed)) {
509 LOCK(&rwl->lock);
510 BROADCAST(&rwl->writeable);
511 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
512 }
513 } else {
514 bool wakeup_writers = true;
515
516 /*
517 * Reset the flag, and (implicitly) tell other writers
518 * we are done.
519 */
520 atomic_fetch_sub_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, WRITER_ACTIVE,
521 memory_order_relaxed);
522 atomic_fetch_add_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, 1,
523 memory_order_relaxed);
524
525 if (rwl->write_granted >= rwl->write_quota ||
526 (atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, memory_order_relaxed) ==
527 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed)) ||
528 (atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->cnt_and_flag, memory_order_relaxed) & ~WRITER_ACTIVE)) {
529 /*
530 * We have passed the write quota, no writer is
531 * waiting, or some readers are almost ready, pending
532 * possible writers. Note that the last case can
533 * happen even if write_requests != write_completions
534 * (which means a new writer in the queue), so we need
535 * to catch the case explicitly.
536 */
537 LOCK(&rwl->lock);
538 if (rwl->readers_waiting > 0) {
539 wakeup_writers = false;
540 BROADCAST(&rwl->readable);
541 }
542 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
543 }
544
545 if ((atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_requests, memory_order_relaxed) !=
546 atomic_load_explicit(&rwl->write_completions, memory_order_relaxed)) &&
547 wakeup_writers) {
548 LOCK(&rwl->lock);
549 BROADCAST(&rwl->writeable);
550 UNLOCK(&rwl->lock);
551 }
552 }
553
554#ifdef ISC_RWLOCK_TRACE
555 print_lock("postunlock",
556 rwl, type);
557#endif
558
559 return (ISC_R_SUCCESS);
560}
